sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider a graph G with 10 vertices and 15 edges. Determine:

1. Whether the graph G has an Eulerian path or not.
2. Whether the graph G has a Hamiltonian path or not.

If the graph G has an Eulerian or a Hamiltonian path, provide the path with the corresponding explanation. If not, justify your answer.
message_2:
1. Eulerian Path:
A graph G has an Eulerian path if and only if it is connected and has exactly 0 or 2 vertices with an odd degree. Since we don't have information about the degrees of the vertices, we cannot determine whether the graph G has an Eulerian path or not without more information.

2. Hamiltonian Path:
A Hamiltonian path is a path that visits each vertex exactly once. Unfortunately, there is no general rule or algorithm to determine if a graph has a Hamiltonian path or not, as it is an NP-complete problem. Therefore, without more information about the structure of the graph G, we cannot determine whether it has a Hamiltonian path or not.
